name: TheAtlantic
text: To shield slavery from the growing force of abolitionism, the most powerful people in the antebellum South circulated racist conspiracy theories. Their lies led the country to war—and still haunt American politics today, Annika Neklason writes. https://t.co/gQPcDTO0Gq

name: TheAtlantic
text: The running joke throughout Greg Daniels’s new Netflix comedy, “Space Force,” is the inanity of American power. That’s hard to laugh at in this particular moment, @sophieGG writes: https://t.co/l2pcDOXjZm

name: TheAtlantic
text: The point of the executive order is to stoke the flames of a culture war, and distract from Trump’s catastrophic mishandling of the COVID-19 pandemic and his dismantling of democracy, @ma_franks writes. https://t.co/MmvIQr8E0z

name: TheAtlantic
text: The president’s two strongest instincts stand pitted against each other: his need for attention and his need to punish enemies, Andrew Ferguson writes. https://t.co/1h1KTT4CqN

name: TheAtlantic
text: After Hurricane Katrina, the government wanted to use the Insurrection Act to deploy troops to New Orleans and treat the city like a war zone. In the podcast series “Floodlines,” Vann R. Newkirk II reports on the man chosen to restore order. https://t.co/tgTGPzjy54 https://t.co/3Tm3T7KZWR

name: TheAtlantic
text: There is a tendency, when examining police violence, to focus on tactics at the expense of strategy, Ta-Nehisi Coates wrote in 2015. “The real problem is the belief that all our social problems can be solved with force.” https://t.co/U0IoA4ivFh

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Spending a year of their life in ... service projects is not what most college students would normally have chosen, but this is not a normal year," @EllenRuppelShel writes. https://t.co/10OR1NyjLd

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: This podcast is remarkably resonant in this moment. Every American should listen: https://t.co/1i79MN1Liv

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: “Humans tend to think of illness as a binary. You are sick or you aren’t, which feels simple and knowable. In reality, most types of communicable disease are far less black and white: People are infected before they become aware that they’re sick.” https://t.co/FYXrURunIi

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @anneapplebaum: History doesn't repeat, but it rhymes https://t.co/ixKmwsJ1v5

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @abdallah_fayyad: .@annalisepasztor’s latest doc shows how quickly people can make adjustments to preserve some normalcy and some comfort in uncertain times. “People are resilient. They want to find ways to still visit and care for each other and love each other.” https://t.co/nNY4JtvHpM

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @annalisepasztor: "Churches in America, I don't know that we really know what persecution is." My latest doc for @TheAtlantic on the unconventional new ways of worshipping during a pandemic:
https://t.co/bN3J7pl6FQ

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: “It is often said that Trump has no real ideology, which is not true—his ideology is white supremacy, in all its truculent and sanctimonious power.” https://t.co/IiLSLYEKDJ

text:

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: "Black males fear racist fear because we know from experience what happens when the police are called, when the Klan is called, when faces are reddened, when purses or ropes or guns are clutched....." -- @DrIbram:
https://t.co/pzrZxhmNJX

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @RonBrownstein: "Look no further than Facebook, which seems to be in a defensive, and sycophantic, crouch as the executive order looms. Zuckerberg today granted an interview to Fox News—already a sign that he’s trying to reach Trump—in which he criticized Twitter’s move: https://t.co/0cnK6FiSnP

text: RT @katlwells: A little more than a year ago, Vann Newkirk told me that he wanted to create a podcast about the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans.
